text: hello this is chef john from food wishes
comm with a new improved HD version of
our poached egg method nothing too
complicated here we pretty much poach
eggs like everybody else except we got a
little step in the middle that makes it
easier if you're doing this for a larger
group all right I'm going to take a
saucepan fill it with cold water on
medium heat I'm going to add some salt
and they say a little bit of acid helps
keep the white together so I put a
little drizzle of any kind of white
vinegar I actually used champagne
vinegar and you're probably thinking
isn't that kind of a waste of an
expensive vinegar yes yes it is so the
most important factor here is the heat
you want to lower your flame until you
have a very light slow gentle simmer it
should look like that next we're going
to take our eggs we want really really
fresh eggs the fresher the better the
fresher they are the better they stay
together in the water another tip I like
to crack them in a ramekin and then take
the ramekin to the water because if the
yolk breaks it doesn't mess up our water
very simple I'm going to plop that in
and oh my god look at that that egg must
have been like a month old look at it
spread out that is worst-case scenario
now a lesser chef would have thrown this
away gone out and found real fresh eggs
and done it over so they would look
better that's not me I decided just to
go for it to show you even if you have
the most horribly old eggs in the world
this will still work I mean look at that
it's just a travesty all right but it's
okay watch see what happens
I'm going to put one more egg in there
and in fact these were so horrible I had
to actually skim the top of all the
white that came off so I can even show

one there's not even enough weight to
cover the yolk you're thinking there's
no way you can use that oh I can use it
if you flip it over it'll look normal
nobody you'll know when you plate it up
now what you're looking for here and
it's going to take you about six minutes
the white will be firm to the touch not
hard just barely firm and the yolk will
still be very very loose all right very
soft see that you'll be able to push it
down your finger and you could just
easily pop it if you wanted to okay so
that's done but we're not going to put
these right on a plate we're going to
in ice water why because then I can do
lots of eggs if I have four six people
over it's too hard to poach that many
eggs at once and get them alright by
putting them in ice water it's going to
suspend that cooking the yolks are going
to stay nice and runny just like that by
the way you can refrigerate that
overnight if you want and then when I'm
ready to serve
I simply reheat them in even more gently
simmering water it's just barely barely
bubbling and those are going to go in
there for about a minute and a half it
doesn't take a long time to heat them
through and then you plate up and you
are a brunch god or goddess so it's just
a nice easy sort of cheater step it
makes poached eggs much much easier
because if you poach them right the
first time all you're doing like I said
is reheating them for a minute minute
and a half maybe two minutes at the most
I like to do the old tap etapa on a dry
towel because you don't want any water
